awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Hurricane Response, Governance Structures, and Public Higher Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Public universities face many challenges in their efforts to operate within an environment that is both dominated by political influences and subject to the pressures of market-based competition for necessary resources. Disasters magnify the challenges of managing within this environment, especially when the institution is constrained in its ability to accommodate the unique needs of students who are facing significant difficulties after a natural disaster. The short term disruption caused by a disaster can lead to long-term consequences for public institutions, but many of these more pronounced consequences may not be fully attributable to the effects of the disaster, but instead may be a function of the inability of policy frameworks and administrative structures to adapt to the needs of public institutions and policy beneficiaries after extreme events. Especially important are the financial consequences of enrollment loss and the constraints that come with accreditation structures. This study will use administrative interviews and data on student success to examine the role of policy design in post-disaster decisions and its influence on student success. We hope that our findings will motivate discussions among federal education officials and accreditation organization leaders about the ways in which they may consider options that would enable institutions to better support students in their efforts to rebuild their lives and pursue their educational goals.


Theories of publicness, political control, policy implementation, and the politics of attention mostly speak to the challenges faced by public sector leaders in times of relative stability (not in response to extreme events), and many discussions of disaster response are limited to elected officials and/or federal agencies. This project seeks to examine how these dynamics play out in disaster recovery efforts for public higher education institutions and their students. We will use a mixed methods design, with qualitative interviews of administrators and a quantitative analysis of student data. The study site is Lamar University in Beaumont, TX. The administrative interviews focus on the ways in which efforts to accommodate and support those affected by the storm were influenced by accreditation-related constraints (in this case, from the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools) and concerns about the effects on funding streams (tuition revenue, state appropriations, and federal financial aid). The quantitative analysis examines how the decisions immediately following the storm affected student enrollment and persistence and the extent to which these effects vary by student-level risk factors or level of storm damage for the individual's household.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
College students are a unique population in the context of disaster response. Many experts in disaster management do not consider college students to be a vulnerable population, but education research has clearly documented that many college students are very much a part of vulnerable communities. This study investigates the impacts of disasters on college students, with a focus on the impact Hurricane Harvey on students at a public regional university in Southeast Texas. This project also examines the administrative response to disasters within higher education with a focus on governance structures and managerial perceptions. This study draws on two original surveys (students and faculty/staff), individual student-level academic data, and semi-structured interviews with higher education administrators.

In the quantitative analysis of student-level data following Hurricane Harvey, we found that the direct impacts of the hurricane on housing, transportation, access to technology, and employment were often different across student groups. Students living on campus and graduate students were less affected by the hurricane, reporting a lower likelihood of having damage to their home, loss of transportation, disruption of employment, or limits to their access to technology. However, Black, Latino, Asian, and low income students were significantly more likely to be negatively affected by the storm.

Black, Latino, Asian, and low income students were all more likely to report food insecurity as well, and Black and Asian students were more likely to experience housing instability. Although many student reported mental health effects, these effects were even more prevalent among women and Latino students. Despite these disparities, our analysis of the effects of the storm on academic outcomes yielded little information.

A similar survey was distributed to the faculty and staff at the same institution. Overall, we found that staff suffered far more negative effects of the storm than faculty. Staff were significantly more likely to have their home affected, to lose their home, to be displaced, to lose their vehicle, and to lose most of their possessions than their staff colleagues. Roughly 1 in 5 staff reported substantial issues, compared to 1 in 10 faculty.

The qualitative portion of this project included interviews with multiple leaders at the institution, supplemented with interviews of state and accreditation officials. At the institutional level, the response was dominated by on-the-fly decisionmaking. Although there were some lessons learned from previous extreme weather events, the combination of the uniqueness of extreme weather events and the lack of state funding for infrastructure support results in a just-in-time management approach that limits organizational learning, long-term planning, and the incorporation of best practices. Many individuals discussed the importance of the state agency’s decision to give institutions a specific deadline of sorts for reopening without requiring a meaningful shift in their operations. In doing so, they created huge incentives for institutions to push forward regardless of whether they were ready to do so. The institutions were also concerned about the effects on accreditation, especially if they were in their re-accreditation year or the year prior. These concerns stemmed from the sheer logistical challenges related to data collection, concerns about continuity, and the near complete lack of formal guidance in the accreditation policies.

In reflecting on the response, many identified the pre-existing infrastructure for supporting online teaching as an important asset in supporting their institutional response. In discussions about the greatest obstacles, communication within the institution was the most commonly identified issue.

Interestingly, interviews with officials at the coordinating board and the accreditation body yield very different approaches and viewpoints, compared to institutional leaders. The accreditation agency was very institution-focused and offered meaningful flexibility (but only for those who sought out accommodations). The coordinating board was more student focused and less concerned about individual institutions, which created a bit of a chilling effect on state-institutional partnerships and multi-institutional collaboration.

Overall, our study finds clear evidence of vulnerability among college students (and college employees) after a disaster event. These patterns of vulnerability align with much of the existing scholarship on vulnerability in disasters and should be considered when discussing emergency management plans in higher education. We find that greater coordination and clarity among institutional, state, federal, and accreditation leaders would likely facilitate more open and effective management going forward.
